title: Americans Want Politicians to Fix Problems, Not Fight
content:
For as long as there have been conversations about women in politics , the question has always been : How would things be different if women were really in charge ? Well , of course , not all women are the same . But my hunch is that if more of us took positions of leadership -- particularly mothers -- policymaking would be less about one-upsmanship , and more about problem solving . Like every mama bear who has gotten two warring siblings to play cooperatively in the back seat of a car , female leaders are often accustomed to making peace between warring factions .
A decade ago , I founded an organization called No Labels not because I am a woman , but because I believed that Washington had become too caught up in partisan warfare . At the time , no one thought we could succeed -- - that we were on a fool ’ s errand . ( Fellow female entrepreneurs : Let me know if you ’ ve ever heard that one before . ) Today , our organization has more than 1 million followers online , and we ’ ve got allies in Congress who are re-establishing the bipartisan ethos that used to prevail in Washington .
I realize that No Labels hasn ’ t succeeded because I ’ m a woman , or because we have so many terrific female leaders on staff and in our network of supporters . It ’ s succeeded because the animating idea of our movement -- that solving the nation ’ s problems depends on people with divergent points of view hashing through their differences -- is as American as apple pie .
No Labels inspired the creation of the Problem Solvers Caucus , a bloc of 48 members of Congress , evenly split between Democrats and Republicans , who have come up with bipartisan solutions on health care , gun safety , infrastructure , immigration and border security , and more . And they ’ re just getting started .
You won ’ t see a lot about our work in the newspapers or cable news -- let alone on social media -- because we aren ’ t about one-liners , zingers , and insults . We ’ re not looking to tear apart anyone ’ s constructive idea , no matter which political party they ’ re from . But here ’ s what I know : For all that people love to watch politics like they ’ re attending a professional wrestling match , what most Americans really want is for their leaders to solve problems creatively . And we ’ re trying to make the space for them to do that .
On Nov. 3 , this Sunday , we are hosting a Problem Solver Convention in Manchester , N.H. Our theory is simple : For all the bickering between presidential candidates , people are hungry for moments where candidates explain how they ’ re going to bring the country together . For one afternoon , in a room full of Democrats and Republicans , that ’ ll be what ’ s on tap . Maybe it won ’ t be as exciting as the insults regularly flung around at the debates . But that ’ s okay with us . As every mother knows , nothing ’ s more satisfying than hearing your children gab happily in the back seat as you drive calmly back home .
